column1: Maybe you have a kid nearby you can give the Krypto to.

column2: Krypto Team-Up: 2018 brought us some sets for DC Super Heroes which all share the ability to combine and includes a brand new plethora of accessory elements created specifically for Super Heroes. Overall this was an interesting design choice, and the cheapest set included a brand new character. The Main Man Lobo himself. This is an awesome set and here&rsquo
column3: s why you should buy it.

column1: Box: With the Justice League logo and characters drawn on the front of the box to indicate what these sets are based on the box design shows off everything that is featured in the set. It&rsquo
column2: s a very nice group of shots on the back and the front has a very impressive action shot on the front.

column1: Instructions: A single manual this time around keeping everything in one book. When multiple models are split between numbered manuals siblings and friends can share the duty of building two different models, when it&rsquo
column2: s just one manual this means sharing the build experience. Something I only recently thought of, as an AFOL I tend to forget kids might like to build with their friends or siblings. A sticker sheet is also included

column1: Most of the details in this set are stickers and not printed elements so there are a lot of useful elements from the set. What I find most interesting is the new effects elements introduced this year in the Super Hero sets, you have energy blasts that can peg into holes or be held by Minifigures and some energy effects which can slide over the hand of the Minifigure to make them look like they&rsquo
column2: re powering their punches with energy. All very impressive elements and with so much potential for interesting builds.

column1: Lobo: Not exactly a villain, more like an Anti-Hero, Lobo works for cash and the highest bidder. His Minifigure is very well done using the new Aquaman hair piece in black and featuring dual-sided facial printing with an expression of joy on one side and anger on the other. He also has The Man written on the back of his jacket because Lobo is the Main Man. No leg printing. There&rsquo
column2: s a brick built mcguffin in this set and Lobo is taking it to Lex Luthor or something&hellip
column3: I have no idea what the canister is meant to represent as I haven&rsquo
column5: s description for this set recently, but I suspect it is some form of kryptonite or alien energy that Lex is after.

column1: Krypto: Krypto the Super Dog uses parts which are similar to the LEGO Scooby-Doo animal. This character has a unique head and body parts, Krypto has one front paw designed to actually hold accessories, which is something Scooby could not do, and so these parts are brand new and not re-used. A cape can be attached via the neck peg adding to the overall look of the Super Dog. A great looking character to get in this set.
Superman: The Man of Steel hasn&rsquo
column2: t changed much since first becoming a Minifigure. This one uses all of the same parts as we&rsquo
column3: ve seen on other Superman Minifigures, gone is the S-Curl hair piece and in its place is the newer DCEU sculpted hair element from Justice League. So this is a hodgepodge of parts from different eras to make a somewhat familiar looking character.

column1: Bag #1: Superman and Krypto are found inside this bag and you get to build a Kryptonite powered prison for Superman as well as the main engine of Lobo&rsquo
column2: s space hog. Don&rsquo
column3: t ask me if he actually has a name for her, my experience with Lobo is really limited. The build is relatively simple and easily enough built within twenty or so minutes. A few stickers are applied on some 1x2 sloped elements for details.

column1: Bag #2: Lobo roars in on his completely space hog once you finish the build in this bag, the build itself is fairly straight forward and there isn&rsquo
column2: t much to be worried about. Only one sticker is applied to a white Nexo Shield element for the detailing.
s Space Hog: I can&rsquo
column3: t recall if he named his space cycle, but Lobo&rsquo
column4: s ride is a huge impressive looking variation on a Speeder Bike. You heard me right, this thing looks somewhat similar to the Star Wars speeder bikes, except it has two side mounted engines and a classic angular fin sticking out from the seat. Lobo&rsquo
column5: s ride is as awesome as he is and quite resilient, it&rsquo
column6: s also a pretty impressive model and features two stud shooters for play features. You can also remove something from the central engine, but for the life of me I&rsquo
column7: m not sure exactly why that is. Solid model though, the lone sticker is a tad unfortunate as the Nexo Shield element should have been able to feature the skull-head detailing as a print honestly.

column1: Kryptonite Prison: This entire section is meant to attach to Lex&rsquo
column2: s mech from the larger 50$ set. As such it may seem a bit awkward looking on its own&hellip
column3: this is mostly because it is a minor build and looks somewhat similar to the stands used to hold the Ultimate Nexo Knights from that theme as the build is fairly similar in parts use for the base of the model. There is a slight bit more parts for this compared to the Ultimate Nexo Knights&rsquo
column4: stands, but not by much. Overall a quirky little side-build that works best if you also own the Lex set from 2018 to attach it to.

column1: This is a nice little set in the 25$ range and features a lot of potential design elements that can be interpreted anyway you&rsquo
column2: d care to during play. The set features three characters and is a must have for Lobo alone as I highly doubt we&rsquo
column3: ll see him again in LEGO form for a while. It would be best to pick this one up while you can as the DC line seems to sell out consistently these days making it all the more harder to find, especially at these price points. Strongly recommended for DC fans and fans of classic space hogs.
